title: Jewish Groups Condemn Invitation Of Iran Ahmadinejad To Hungarian University
message:
Hungarian Jewish organizations, alongside the Israeli embassy, have voiced strong condemnation against a public university in Hungary for extending an invitation to Iran's former president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, to participate in an academic event this week.
The Ludovika University of Public Service, based in Budapest, sparked outrage by inviting Ahmadinejad, known for his vehemently anti-Israel and antisemitic rhetoric.
In response to the university's decision, two prominent Hungarian Jewish congregations, along with a Jewish advocacy group, issued a joint statement today denouncing Ahmadinejad's visit as "openly antisemitic."
AP PhotoThe statement urges Ludovika University to reconsider its decision and to reflect on the implications of providing a platform for an individual known for promoting toxic ideologies.
Hungary's Foreign Ministry has said that the government refrains from interfering in university programs, suggesting a hands-off approach to the university's decision-making process.

Details: Ludovika University extended an invitation to Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, known for his anti-Israel and antisemitic rhetoric, sparking condemnation from Hungarian Jewish organizations and the Israeli embassy.

Event: Joint condemnation of Ahmadinejad's visit by Hungarian Jewish organizations
Location: Budapest, Hungary
Details: Hungarian Jewish congregations and advocacy groups issued a statement denouncing Ahmadinejad's visit as openly antisemitic and urging Ludovika University to reconsider its decision.

title: David Cameron pledges to build  vital  Holocaust Memorial and Learning Centre alongside Parliament
message:
Politicians across the political spectrum have renewed their calls for a Holocaust Memorial and Learning Centre to be constructed on the lawn alongside parliament.
The event, hosted by the UK Holocaust Memorial Foundation, the Holocaust Memorial All Party Parliamentary Group and the Holocaust Education Trust (HET), saw speeches from Foreign Secretary Lord David Cameron, shadow cabinet member Lisa Nandy MP, and Holocaust survivor Susan Pollack OBE.
In the face of rising antisemitism, Lord Cameron said that a permanent national Holocaust memorial in Victoria Tower Gardens is needed now more than ever.
Bob Blackman MP and Lord Ian Austin, co-chairs of the Holocaust Memorial All Party Parliamentary Group commented that it’s been nearly ten years since the Holocaust Memorial and Learning Centre was announced and still “no ground has been broken and not one brick laid.
The need for progress on the memorial and learning centre has never been more urgent.”

title: Jewish Columbia students push back against campus antisemitism
message:

A STUDENT protester waves a Palestinian flag above Hamilton Hall on the campus of Columbia University in New York, in late April.
(credit: MARY ALTAFFER/REUTERS)The letter listed instances of aggressive and dehumanizing rhetoric leveled at the Jewish students not just since the April 17 encampment that was expelled last Wednesday, but in response to Hamas's October 7 Massacre.
Much of the antisemitism encountered by the students was an inversion of the "Holocaust legacy," said the students.
The situation became so tense with the establishment of the tent settlement aimed at forcing the administration to adopt anti-Israel policies, that Orthodox Union Jewish Learning Initiative on Campus director rabbi Elie Buechler warned Jewish students to leave campus for the Passover holiday.

title: Opinion : My experience at the Columbia University encampment
message:
Lily ForandLargely because of my age, I was privileged to hear student protesters’ unfiltered passion, instead of the defensive stance elicited by more skeptical senior reporters often looking for an angle with shock value.
One video in particular shows a protester holding up a sign to pro-Israeli demonstrators that read “Al-Qasam’s Next Targets.” It’s unclear whether the perpetrator was affiliated with Columbia University; nevertheless, this and other documented incidents are clearly unacceptable.
After visiting the encampment and speaking to students, I’ve come away with a much clearer picture of the goals and behavior I believe defined the majority of protesters at the Columbia encampment.
Students set up a library at the encampment and walked around handing out cold cloths to anyone who was overheating.
Dalia, a Palestinian freshman at Columbia, explained that her peers were more “united” than ever and overwhelmingly supported university divestment from companies with Israeli ties (76.55%).
